Appearance
From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: stunde, stünde, and stuņde

German

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German stunde, from Old High German stunta, from Proto-West Germanic *stundu, from Proto-Germanic *stundō (“point in time, hour”).

Cognate with Catalan estona (“while”), Hunsrik Stunn (“while, hour”), Low German Stunn, Stünn (“hour”), dated Dutch stond (“time”), English stound (“hour, while, moment, time”), Danish stund (“while”), Norwegian stund (“while”), Northern Sami stund (“while”), Finnish tunti (“hour”). More at stound.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈʃtʊndə/
  • Audio (Germany):(file)
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)
  • Audio (Austria):(file)

Noun

[edit]

Stunde f (genitive Stunde, plural Stunden, diminutive Stündchen n or Stündlein n)

  2. hour (unit of time consisting of 60 minutes)
    Der Film dauert drei Stunden.
    The movie lasts three hours.
  4. (dated) hour, moment, time (point in time)
    Bitte für uns Sünder, jetzt und in der Stunde unsres Todes.
    Pray for us sinners, now and at the hour of our death.
  6. lesson; class (teaching unit, usually between 45 and 90 minutes)
    Ich muss jetzt zur Klavierstunde.
    I need to go to piano class right now.

Usage notes

[edit]
  • The term Zeitstunde (literally “time-hour”) may be used in education contexts to distinguish sense 1 from sense 3.

Declension

[edit]
Declension of Stunde [feminine]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative eine die Stunde die Stunden
genitive einer der Stunde der Stunden
dative einer der Stunde den Stunden
accusative eine die Stunde die Stunden

Descendants

[edit]
  • → Kashubian: sztënia
  • → Lower Sorbian: štunda
  • → Yiddish: שטונדע (shtunde)
  • → Latvian: stunda
  • → Slovincian: sztënja
